body: The changes in this MR were merged with #565

@conradsp what bothers me slightly (but not enough to not merge this, after we clarify the small question, above, so this just FYI) is that as we get this on Docker Hub (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-18673), we're going to be pushing a container image with a hard-ocded DB URL that is specific to `docker compose` .. I'd like to eventually contribute e.g. Kubernetes deployment steps, where the DB would be differerent. I can't really think of a better solution for this problem right now either though.

Thanks Michael - I agree with your comments. As soon as
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-765 is merged, I will remove
the build.gradle changes in the Dockerfile.

Will continue to think about a more robust solution. Ideally the db seeding
scripts will not have a db hostname encoded at all and would pull that from
an environment variable (defaulting to localhost or some sane default).

Thanks,
Steve

@meysholdt (/Cc @svenefftinge) FYI the mysql in the "worker container" (or whatever you call it) is very slow, noticeable slower than on a developer workstation, and it takes a non-negligable amount of time to start this project, because it runs (a lot of) DB Schema mgiration scripts (using Flyway) at boot... I don't suppose there is some way to grant the "Terminal container" (?) a higher priority? Just asking.
https://github.com/gitpod-io/gitpod/issues/648
@conradsp how about this?  Plz merge if OK for you... thanks!
Would be interesting to learn what makes mysql slow in the container. The nodes are pretty powerful and the database sits on an SSD. @meysholdt any idea? (cc @jankeromnes)

There is no idea on the top of my head. As you said, the hardware is good :) 

MySQL runs with this config:
https://github.com/gitpod-io/workspace-images/blob/master/mysql/mysql.cnf

Maybe the config holds some flags which are not optimal?

@vorburger how dos your MySQL config look like when MySQL performs well?
Thanks @vorburger - that's a good addition. Will merge.
@conradsp you merged this wihout noticing it broke the build... :smile: #600 fixes it.

Thanks @vorburger! Darn RAT checks! :)

@vorburger - I verified that it builds correctly. 😄 Merging now.

Please do not merge this yet, I just noticed that we actually have a bigger problem to fix first in #602, then rebase this on that, and then this will illustrate a number of problems we should fix first, and only then merge this.

Perhaps this PR (also..) should wait until we're fully done with the Gradle upgrade (although I initally built it to help me understand a problem I ran into there). This is because it points out `/home/vorburger/.gradle/wrapper/dists/gradle-2.10-bin/baigpnfu14tdk6ztbfwcl8275/gradle-2.10/lib/groovy-all-2.4.4.jar` as having CP dupes of groovy-2.3.6.jar - but the former should never be on the application's runtime classpath anyway.. not sure if this was a bug in Gradle 2.10 which is perhaps fixed in later versions?
This will definitely first also require #607 (and probably more).

I may actually need Jasper later again when upgrading Tomcat 7.0.54 to 8.5.42 (where `com.radcortez.gradle:openjpa-gradle-plugin` does not start without Jasper..), so if this is causing any other problems, we can also just forget about it. I'll close it.
self merging trivial change which passed TravisCI build and has 0 risk...
Given how we're using Slf4j everywhere else, and that this PR passed the TravisCI build, this seems very low risk to me, so I'm going to go ahead and exceptionally self merge this trivial change.
@conradsp @vishwasbabu @ShruthiRajaram @awasum @Anh3h could anyone review and merge this one? Tx!

@conradsp review? Specifically re. container (Docker) - but if anything you should jump up :joy: in joy, because this aligns the version we use for `integrationTest` with the `bitnami/tomcat:7.0.94` you've used in the (new) `Dockerfile` ... so fine for you, I guess?

@vishwasbabu would this be OK for you, any objections, or could you merge it?
see #613
/Cc @michaelbukachi

I suggest that we ignore the entire Flyway related discussion (above, in previous inline review discussions), I think I actually got it work in the end now, but all that was more of a "distraction" re. the main point of this effort (the Gradle upgrade) - because we (probably) will just remove Flyway from Gradle anyway, see #613.

But what we do still need to do here is to get `./gradlew integrationTest`to pass on this branch/PR - it currently does not, because Tocmcat does not fully start (it starts but seems to ignore Fineract WAR completely), see `build/reports/tests/integrationTest/classes/org.apache.fineract.integrationtests.AccountNumberPreferencesTest.html`.

The interesting thing is that `./gradlew tomcatRunWAR` does work though! I've not yet understood what the difference / root cause of this is, and would very much welcome input from anyone who is able to dig more into this... anyone able to help and step up here?

PS: In the mean time I started exploring just completely ditching Tomcat and using only Spring Boot, but I have concluded that may be too big a step in one go - if at all possible, I think it would be much better & clearer to just wrap up this PR with a more narrow focused upgrade of Gradle and the minimal required adjustments, only - and then only separately after follow-up re. running integration tests with Spring Boot instead of Tomcat (FINERACT-764).
@vorburger  Let me look into this. I've successfully made integration test run locally.
Awesome stuff! I too never use the flyway plugin to run any tasks. So I find no use for it.

Looks fine to me. Builds successfully. Merging.
Yes, this is good. Now let's get to Tomcat 8! :) @vishwasbabu, please merge if OK with you.
Thanks @vorburger. I have validated that the docker build runs fine and we no longer need to modify build.gradle in the Dockerfile. @vishwasbabu - you can merge if all looks good to you.

Re. Tomcat 8, my preference would be to ditch pre-historical times (AKA WAR
files), and just do regular Spring Boot (with java -jar
fineract-provider.war via embedded Tomcat, whatever version, not our
problem- in theory).

>
You are right @vorburger .. java -jar file.war(jar) works well with Docker too..as cloud native becomes even popular.

PS: Bval = https://bval.apache.org
On it... @vorburger
@vorburger - I agree 100% on getting rid of Tomcat dependency. As @awasum indicated, running as a straight jar would be the best option.

@marta-jankovics - just FYI, we are removing the notempty annotation as indicated above. This should not affect functionality of interoperability layer. The NotNull checks should take care of any edge cases.

@vorburger - could you please add a NotNull annotation on the InteropIdentifierRequestData constructor for the accountId field: 

`public InteropIdentifierRequestData(@NotNull InteropIdentifierType idType, @NotNull String idValue, String subIdOrType, String accountId) {	    public InteropIdentifierRequestData(@NotNull InteropIdentifierType idType, @NotNull String idValue, String subIdOrType, String accountId) 
`

should become:

`public InteropIdentifierRequestData(@NotNull InteropIdentifierType idType, @NotNull String idValue, String subIdOrType, String accountId) {	    public InteropIdentifierRequestData(@NotNull InteropIdentifierType idType, @NotNull String idValue, String subIdOrType, @NotNull String accountId) 
`

After that, it looks good to me and I can merge (or you can go ahead and merge).
@vorburger

@NotEmpty
"The annotated element must not be {@code null} nor empty."
@NotNull 
"The annotated element must not be {@code null}"
so to me it seems that if you replace @NotEmpty with @NotNull you would affect the functionality.
Looks good to me. Integration tests are passing.

@mohitsinha It will be helpful to take sometime and add tests for the feature you provided. If there is no test for that module, then its recommended to invest some time and put tests for maintenance purposes.

Imagine the next person who works on this particular file or feature type also does not write a test, it means over time, we will keep merging without tests. This can create a situation where we are creating features without test all because.. "it works manually".  Set the foundation so your future should be easy to manage.

We will look at this after gradle upgrade
This looks to me.
@awasum But the root cause of this infrequent random failure should be found out. Making the test reports public after travis run can be benefecial.

FTR: I lococally tested that `./gradlew test` still passes on `develop` with this merged after #602 (because I probably had raised this PR before noticing the bigger problem in #602), and wanted to make sure we didn't accidentially break thing - it's fine, this test still passes, even now that we are actually really running unit tests again.

>  so to me it seems that if you replace @notempty with @NotNull you would affect the functionality.

@marta-jankovics yes, I agree, this affects functionality in the sense that it no longer checks for empty String in a few of the InteropIdentifierRequest/Response fields.

The point here, which I should have made much more clear in the initial comment proposing this, is the following: This [Apache BVal](https://bval.apache.org) `@NotEmpty` annotation is used ONLY in InteropIdentifierRequest/Response, and nowhere else in all of Fineract. (I've updated the title to more accurately reflect this.)

This use blocks #607, which blocks #601, which would help to clean up with seems to be a classpath mess.

So I'm proposing that we simplify things by removing our dependency on BVal, understanding that we loose a (minor?) convenience (?) use of `@NotEmpty` annotation. I doubt that was actually ever intended to be available at all - it's, likely, more of a side effect of the (wrong) use of `openjpa-all` (which is a "shaded" JAR which contains far to much). 

I'm also not entirely sure if this  `@NotEmpty` annotation check even actually worked? At least [the OpenJPA documentation makes no mention of Apache BVal, or even any annotation based validation](http://openjpa.apache.org/builds/2.4.3/apache-openjpa/docs/manual.html).

Long story short, I'm suggesting this (very minor) change despite it (possibly, not even sure) causing a minor regression in checking for (unlikely?) empty fields in one particular request.

The alternative would be to add a real integration test for `@NotEmpty`, and if that currently works, add an explicit dependency to BVal, or some other artifact JAR with these validation annotations. To me, both seem unnecessary, and avoiding it will likely reduce other dependency issues (in #601 I'd like to try to clean up what, to me, currently seems to be a bit of a mess in terms of Fineracts depenencies).

@awasum @mohitsinha re. giving more details about test failures on Travis CI, you may be be interested in reading the comments and linked issues re. the back and forth for `./gradlew test` with and without `--info` [at the end of .travis.yml](https://github.com/apache/fineract/blob/develop/.travis.yml) ...

Oh and BTW I just stumbled upon this in `fineract-provider/build.gradle` :

    exclude module: 'bval-core'
    exclude module: 'org.apache.bval.bundle'
    exclude module: 'bval-jsr303'

So in the past someone actually tried to actively prevent the use of Apache BVal at some point - but because of `openjpa-all`, it sneaked (back?) in; this, with #607, will clean that up.

Erm... further work on #607 has now revealed that we actually very much do need a Bean Validation provider, such as Apache BVal (or Hibernate Validator; but we currently use BVal, through `openjpa-all`); without one, Spring start-up fails saying: `javax.validation.NoProviderFoundException: Unable to create a Configuration, because no Bean Validation provider could be found. Add a provider like Hibernate Validator (RI) to your classpath.`

I'm therefore closing this PR, as I'll likely be adding an explicit dependency to BVal over in #607 after all.

Sorry for the noise! :smiling_imp:

Nah, re-opening this after all... what we really should do here, to avoid future confusion, is just replace `org.apache.bval.constraints.NotEmpty` with `javax.validation.constraints.NotEmpty` ... just done - OK for you all to merge this like?  (PS: I'll, probably make Apache BVal an `implementation` instead of `compile` scoped dependency in #607; see [FINERACT-777](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-777).
GitHub someone doesn't let me re-open this PR anymore, so #617.
@marta-jankovics @conradsp

I've looked into this again (see forced push updated), but it will need more work to pass.. the change from `openjpa-all` to `openjpa` means that we need to make some more adjustments to re. the previously shaded dependencies.

This looks good - I agree with using javax.validation and removing bval. I have validated that it builds successfully and will not affect interoperability functionality. Merging.

I've just rebased this on latest `develop`, and resolved conflicts with recently merged changes.

As before, `./gradlew integrationTest` still fails. @michaelbukachi have you had any luck debugging this?

@vorburger Not yet. I'm trying to run `./gradlew tomcatRun` to make sure the server is starting smoothly, but I'm getting a ` Could not get unknown property 'classesDir' for main classes of type org.gradle.api.internal.tasks.DefaultSourceSetOutput`. **classesDir** was deprecated in 4 and removed 5. I'm trying to find out which plugin is causing it so that I can update it.

@vorburger It seems the tomcat plugin being used, `org.gradle.api.plugins:gradle-tomcat-plugin:1.0` is incompatible with **gradle 5**. Changing it to `com.bmuschko:gradle-tomcat-plugin:2.5` and also changing `apply plugin: 'tomcat` to `apply plugin: 'com.bmuschko.tomcat'` removes the error.
@vorburger Are we still using the drizzle driver?

> (although strangely I didn't run into that issue; curious)

Hey @vorburger. Are you referring to the *`:enhance`* issue? Or the *`:metamodel`* issue? Apologies for the confusion between the two. 

The *`:enhance`* issue that I referred to [*here*](https://github.com/vorburger/fineract/pull/1#issuecomment-509453457) and the *`:metamodel`* issue that I referred to [*here*](https://github.com/radcortez/openjpa-gradle-plugin/issues/8#issue-464995001), are separate issues — *though on the same plugin* — discovered under separate scenarios. It is very likely, I suspect, that the two issues are related somehow.

I discovered the *`:enhance`* issue immediately after I cloned the fineract project. The very first thing I did as a sanity check, was run *`gradle check`* on the project. That failed, [*producing this stack trace*](http://bit.ly/RadCrtzNhnc). However, I proceeded with [*my`api/implementation` changes*](http://bit.ly/FinerPR1) regardless, by working around that. I simply excluded the problematic task with *`gradle -x :enhance ...`* whenever I needed to build the project.

After I was finished, I was still curious why the *`:enhance`* task had failed. So I investigated by creating a simple, stripped-down standalone project that only applied the *`com.radcortez.gradle:openjpa-gradle-plugin:3.0.0`*. That simple project did not include any of the other dependencies that fineract has. 

It was under that scenario that I discovered the radcortez plugin's *`:metamodel`* issue.  [*Here's the stack trace I encountered*](https://github.com/radcortez/openjpa-gradle-plugin/files/3368461/openjpa-gradle-plugin.issue.8.a.txt) in that scenario. 

It's possible that the reason you have not encountered [*the `:metamodel` issue*](http://bit.ly/RadCrtz8) in the fineract project, might be because [*the `:metamodel` task/extension*](http://bit.ly/RadCrtzMeta) must be explicitly ran/configured in order to reproduce [*the issue I reported*](http://bit.ly/RadCrtz8). Whereas, the *`:enhance`* task is automatically ran as part of any Gradle build that includes Gradle's built-in *`classes`* task; such as the *`gradle :check`* task.

Or is it possible that some admixture of all of the dozens of different dependencies in the fineract project affects the behavior of the radcortez plugin? Could it be that some combination of direct dependencies and transitive dependencies in fineract are masking or eliminating the radcortez plugin issue for you? Or maybe I'm only seeing issues on my machine because of development environment-related differences? Like OS or whatever? I'm on Windows 7 Professional 64 bit.

Perhaps you could like to pull this and confirm that for you it works with this as it stands now?

> @vorburger Are we still using the drizzle driver?

yeah, see #613 and [FINERACT-765](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-765) and note _this does not affect e.g. " ./gradlew createDB -PdbName=mifosplatform-tenants", that will still work (and is really quite useful), because createDB has nothing to do with Flyway._

> how weird that I didn't hit this...

Heads-up @vorburger, About an hour or so ago (*probably before you wrote your above comment*) I pulled down [*your java11 branch*](http://bit.ly/VrbrgrJ11) to see what I could make of [*the apache#609 failure*](http://bit.ly/Trvs609J11) you mentioned in our earlier conversation. 

The very first thing I always do immediately after pulling down a new branch is I run *`gradle check`* to make sure all is well. This is what I got on your *`java11`* branch:

```
FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.
...
* What went wrong:
A problem occurred evaluating root project 'fineract-provider'.
> Could not get unknown property 'classesDir' for main classes of type org.gradle.api.internal.tasks.DefaultSourceSetOutput.
...
BUILD FAILED in 2m 19s
```

A grep on *`classesDir`* turned up this:

```
$ grep -n -R 'classesDir' fineract-provider
fineract-provider/build.gradle:75:    files = fileTree(sourceSets.main.output.classesDir).matching {
fineract-provider/build.gradle:329:sourceSets.main.output.resourcesDir = sourceSets.main.output.classesDir
fineract-provider/build.gradle:330:sourceSets.test.output.resourcesDir = sourceSets.test.output.classesDir
fineract-provider/build.gradle:369:    testClassesDir = project.sourceSets.integrationTest.output.classesDir

```

> how weird that I didn't hit this...

P.S. @vorburger , [*The apache#609 CI failure*](http://bit.ly/Trvs609J11) is most likely due to the last change to [*fineract-provider/gradle/wrapper/gradle-wrapper.properties*](http://bit.ly/GrdlWrpr210) being four+ years ago. Version 2.10 of the wrapper needs to be updated to at least 5.2.x I believe.

FTR: This is pending either #525 (Gradle upgrade in Fineract) or https://github.com/gitpod-io/gitpod/issues/648 (making it possible to use older Gradle versions in GitPod.io); without either of those solved, it does not actually work.

see #619 for one possible use of this - but I think it's handy more generally.

Would anyone have any concerns / objections to adding this?

I don't really know the endpoints exposed by actuator by default for this particular version.
Just to be sure, I think we should only enable those actuator endpoints that we need.
The endpoints exposed by this particular version of actuator should be safe. Or, we can manually configure the endpoints that we need.

Can you describe how the system's gradle is called when in fact you call `./gradew`? 

I opened https://gitpod.io/#github.com/apache/fineract/pull/598 and the following commands resulted in "build successful":
```
./gradlew createDB -PdbName=mifosplatform-tenants;
./gradlew createDB -PdbName=mifostenant-default;
./gradlew test
```

> > This has a number of pre-requisites

Oh! I just figured it out. Basically, as was actually pretty obvious just from staring at the console (as always, once you see it...), `./gradlew integrationTest` indeed just no longer started Tomcat - that `doFirst` thing to launch `tomcatRunWar.daemon = true` just seems to not work anymore when upgrading  Gradle from 2.10 to 5.2.1 (and there is no error message about that at all, shame on you, Gradle).
